bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William H. Wranek, Jr., November 4, 1947

div1.p: Hench writes that he will send Wranek a copy of his speech on Reed at the University of Virginia. He discusses the content of the speech and notes that he emphasizes Lazear's contribution as well as Reed's.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William H. Wranek, Jr., November 4, 1947
div1.opener:
November 4, 1947
Mr. William H. Wranek, Jr.
University News Service
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Wranek:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly the interest which you and Mr. John Cook
Wyllie are taking in my forthcoming visit to Charlottesville and I will
make every effort to interest my audience in the story of Walter Reed
and the conquest of yellow fever. Incidentally, the title of the talk
could almost be “The University of Virginia and the Conquest of Yellow
Fever” because three Virginia men (Walter Reed, Major, now General
Jefferson R. Kean, and John J. Moran) had much to do with the affair.

You asked me to send you ahead of time a copy of my talk and
I will try to do so. However, I have not yet determined exactly the
context of the talk. This depends on the length of time allowed to me.
On previous occasions the first half of my talk concerns the human in-
terest story of the conquest of yellow fever. I can assure you that I
am not going to give a medical or scientific talk. It will be completely
understandable and I hope will interest the layman. It is the human
story, not the medical story, that I will tell. The second part of my
talk, about the last third, I have devoted in the past to the rather
amusing way in which we discovered the lost Camp Lazear (where Walter
Reed did his work) and the remains of one of Reed's little experimental
buildings, and I also touch briefly on the finding by me in various
attics and collars of many old letters, documents, etc., pertaining to
the conquest of yellow fever. My audiences have seemed to be interested
and amused by this last part, but the whole thing as I have given it in
the past takes a whole hour and I am not sure that my hosts want me to
talk that long this time. It may be, therefore, that I will have to con-
fine myself just to the first part of the story.

Although I am pleased with your courteous thought that my talk
might be of some news value (you even mentioned sending items air mail
to the news bureaus in South America) I fear that the talk will have
little or nothing of interest to you from that angle. I can hardly be-
lieve that the following would be timely: “FLASH -- WALTER REED CONQUERS
YELLOW FEVER” or “FLASH -- UNIVERSITY BOY MAKES GOOD”. You see what I
mean. There is certainly nothing of any special news value in the first
part of my talk even though I do have some new angles to it and include
certain heretofore unknown or little known data on just what this man and
that man did. This is mostly of interest as a human document, a story
of courage and heroism or of interest to medical historians.

In a very modest way, there might be some news interest in
the fact that a rather important collection of historical data on Walter
Reed and his associates is being accomplished. It would have been tragic
had these collections in various attics and cellars not been sought and
brought together and some of the material that I have assembled is of
rather important historical value. But that would hardly rate more than
an inch or two in your own University News or in some medical magazine.
I enclose a carbon copy of a list which I just sent to Mr. John Cook
Wyllie and I think that he will agree with the general tone of my letter
and he can also tell you his opinion of the value of this collection.
I am sure that you know that when a couple of bibliophiles and historians
get together they can get quite excited about something which sounds
completely ridiculous to others.

There is one little part of my talk which I will have to tell
at the risk of offending those who would (erroneously) give Walter Reed
all the credit. My investigations show clearly that the work of Lazear
was of tremendous importance; that he actually in the early phases of
the study was “ahead of Reed” and was sniffing up the right track a
little bit ahead of schedule, prematurely, and “on his own”. As the
result of certain secret experiments, it was he who first proved that
the mosquito was the cause of yellow fever but died leaving incomplete
data which proved the point conclusively to Reed but which would have
been unacceptable to the world without the further magnificent and con-
clusive experiments of Reed. I would, of course, have to give Lazear
his due credit. But there is so much credit that that extra credit
which we must give Lazear cannot and should not detract one iota from
the glory that is firmly Reed's.

As soon as I hear from my hosts just how long the talk is to
be (I fear it is not going to be at a popular hour, I think someone said
it would be at 5:00 p.m. Who wants to hear a lecture at 5:00 p.m.?) I
can decide on what the talk will be. I will then try to write it out
and send it to you as soon as I can but I fear that you will be greatly
disappointed in its news value.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
